Award.AwardTitle: Analytic number theory and periods of automorphic forms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator proposes several projects in analytic number theory concerning Fourier coefficients of modular forms and moments of L-functions. The investigator will combine spectral methods with formulas which relate these quantities to periods of automorphic forms to establish asymptotic formulas with strong bounds on the error terms. In project 1 the investigator will establish a new asymptotic formula for the Hardy-Ramanujan partition function and thus provide an alternative approach to computing large partition numbers. In project 2 the investigator will use traces of weak Maass forms to construct new examples of mock modular forms and establish asymptotic formulas for their coefficients. In project 3 the investigator will establish asymptotic formulas for moments of L-functions and apply these results to various non-vanishing and subconvexity problems.

Modular forms and L-functions are objects of fundamental importance in number theory. For example, the Fourier coefficients of modular forms contain arithmetic and combinatorial information, while central values of L-functions are related to invariants of elliptic curves. The proposed research will result in a greater understanding of these objects and pave the way for new applications. One such application involves computing large partition numbers, which have important uses in scientific computing and cryptography. The proposed research will also lead to problems suitable for undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows. Some of these problems will be studied by undergraduates advised by the investigator through the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The integer partitions are objects of fundamental importance in number theory. Roughly speaking, a partition of a positive integer n is a collection of positive integers whose sum equals n. For example, if n=4, then the partitions of 4 are given by 4, 3+1=4, 2+2=4, 2+1+1=4, and 1+1+1+1=4. Hence there are five partitions of 4, given by the collections of positive integers (4), (3,1), (2,2), (2,1,1), and (1,1,1,1).

Let p(n) equal the number of partitions of a positive integer n (so, as we have seen, p(4)=5). It quickly becomes difficult to count all of the partitions of n, even for relatively small values of n. For example, if n=200, then p(200)=3,972,999,029,388.

A natural question to ask is: how does the partition function p(n) grow as n becomes large? In other words, can one give a mathematically precise way to measure the size of p(n) without having to computing this number explicitly?

These questions were answered in the early 20th century by Hardy and Ramanujan as part of their celebrated collaboration. To answer these questions, they invented a new method called the circle method, which has since been employed with spectacular success in a wide range of mathematical contexts.

A major objective of this project was to develop new methods, different from the Hardy-Ramanujan circle method, which are useful for studying the partition function p(n) and related combinatorial objects. The investigator developed such methods and successfully employed them to improve the classical results of Hardy, Ramanujan, and others on the growth of p(n). One outcome was a new way to compute large values of p(n), which are of broader scientific interest.

The roots of quadratic polynomials are also objects of fundamental importance in number theory. Suppose we are given a quadratic polynomial of the form aX^2+bX+c whose discriminant D=b^2-4ac is negative. This polynomial has two roots, one of which is a distinguished root called a CM point. If we consider the collection of all such polynomials of discriminant D, then we get a corresponding collection of CM points. It is a remarkable fact that the CM points are distributed in a very uniform way.

Another major objective of this project was to study how the distribution of CM points can be used to estimate exponential sums. To be more precise, many important problems in number theory concern the growth of sums whose terms involve values of exponential functions. The terms in these so-called exponential sums interact with each other in mysterious ways, and understanding this interaction is a subtle and difficult problem which is essential for estimating their growth.  The investigator successfully used the distribution of CM points to give sharp estimates for exponential sums.

In addition to the topics described above, the project significantly impacted research and outreach at the postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate levels. For example, the investigator advised two postdoctoral fellows, two Ph.D. students, and 15 undergraduate students. The undergraduate students were advised primarily as part of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program in mathematics. Three of these students won the NSF Graduate Fellowship, and many of them now attend leading Ph.D. programs in mathematics.

The investigator was also actively involved in outreach activities to the local community through programs such as the Math Circle. These programs are aimed at broadening participation of elementary, middle, and high school students in the mathematical sciences.
